title.italic: Reburn and Return: How Invasive Species Influence Fire Return Intervals in Colorado.

sec.p: Invasive plants and forest fires are significant issues in Colorado. Fire intensity and frequency, as well as the dominance of invasive species are increasing in Colorado. Invasions by non-native plant species after fire can negatively impact important ecosystem services and lead to invasion-fire cycles, which ultimately further degrade ecosystems Prevéy et al. (2024) . Invasive species have negative impacts on ecosystems not limited to fire return intervals. Some of these impacts are disruption of species interactions, impact on successional recovery, introduction and spread of diseases, reduction in native species diversity, and economic losses Gallardo, Clavero, Sánchez, & Vilà (2016).

Certain invasive species can alter fire frequencies and intensities, potentially increasing the occurrence of wildfires Gallardo et al. (2016) . The influence of non-native species on forest fire regimes is complex and varies by vegetative functional type and geographic region Prevéy et al. (2024). This project will examine how different functional groups of invasive species impact fire return intervals, re-establishment rates, and expansion across Colorado.

Furthermore, it has been established that native species rely on soil microbiomes to establish on burned soil, while non-native do not; this makes non-natives more likely to establish quickly after forest fires and then dominate these disturbed sites Escobedo et al. (2024). However, scientific understanding of how to restore plant-soil microbiome interactions after wildfires remains limited, leading to a key knowledge gap in post- fire ecosystem restoration Escobedo et al. (2024). Escobedo’s research was done in a greenhouse in Chile, measuring establishment of native vs. non-native species in burned , unburned, and burned soil that was inoculated with native microbiome species Escobedo et al. (2024). The study found that burned soil had higher levels of available nutrients, which benefited non-native species Escobedo et al. (2024). Furthermore, this study found that native species relied on the native microbiome while non-natives did not Escobedo et al. (2024). Taking this study into account, once we see what invasive species are an issue in Colorado relating to fire intervals, and then use information about plant-soil microbiome interactions from Escobedo to see if this interaction could be furthering the issue. We are not sure exactly how this information will be used, but since it is relevant, we want to keep the option open to explore it. It is likely outside the scope of our research, but we are open to including it if we can find a way to.

In this project, we will compare eight burned sites across Colorado that have experienced wildfires within the past 20 years. Sites will be selected to represent a range of geographic regions and burn severities, enabling analysis of how different conditions influence invasive species dynamics. In addition, two unburned sites serving as control locations will be selected from areas with no recorded wildfires during the same period. This site selection strategy aims to capture variability in post-fire plant communities and better understand the relationship between invasive species re-establishment risk and fire severity.

The main dataset we will be using is current and future projection post-ire invasion risk by non-native short lived forbs and grasses Prevéy et al. (2024). This data is based on vegetation cover data from plots in the Western U.S that burned prior to sampling. Projected invasion risks post-fire were calculated using random forests with gridded climate, topographic predictor, and soil variables by Prevéy et al. (2024) .We will use the data projected under a high emission scenario.

We will also use data from the USFS from 2005 that tracks invasive species prominence ( https://research.fs.usda.gov/products/dataandtools/fia-datamart ). We will compare a total of 10 sites in Colorado that we will compare, trying to spread our sites out geographically and by severity of burn. We will pick sites that had been surveyed in 2005 and are also included in the projection data.

Our projection data is in a spatial format, so we will need to extract data from longitude and latitude of the sites we select. We will also need data that shows fires in Colorado going back to at least 2005 that will include fire severity.

I am still trying to learn how to work with spatial data and need some additional help with getting to a testing phase, but will be in office hours tomorrow.

The first test we will run will be to model the influence of a functional group of invasive species to see how that affects the projection for fire and an invasive return interval. We will try out several models including a linear regression, random forest, and Xgboost. We will also use a Bayesian model to get uncertainty estimates and a more flexible hierarchical structure to represent random effects for the region or species. We will find the best model and then we can use that to make projection predictions for sites that we don’t have projection data for.

The second test we will run is an ANOVA test. With this test we will see if the mean invasion risk across our sights vary significantly. We could also potentially see if the risk of forbs or grasses are significantly different. We could also use this test to see if different burn severitys lead to different invasion risk.

I believe that we have all the data we need for this project between our two datasets. One piece of supplemental data that might be useful is data showing forest fires in Colorado. This would allow us to explore urn severity and its correlation to invasion risk. I think GIS or another form of spatial data would be ideal for this, but we are not sure if we will be able to do this on top of the other goals we have outlined.

A potential challenge is that our historic data counts invasive species, while the projection data projects invasion risk. Therefore we are going to have to figure out a way to make the two different types of data comparable. I think that a visualization of invasive cover could be useful and might help to bridge that gap.

Along with handling spatial data, we also grapple with how we carry out our approaches. In addition to ANOVA, linear regression, random forest, and XGBoost models will be used to assess associations between fire severity, vegetation cover, and invasion threat. These models will inform us of linear and non-linear relationships and allow us to assess predictive performance. Spatial autocorrelation is also an issue as it could affect results if areas close to one another are too alike each other. Finally, as invasion and fire are persistent processes, it could be difficult to see evident patterns with predominantly new data, and therefore model calibration and validation would be an important part of our methodology.

The methods including ANOVA and learning models like random forest and XGBoost, will enable us to identify the most important predictors of invasive species spread and their effects on fire return intervals. Using a suite of methods, we will assess the extent to which different factors—like fire severity and region—drive invasion risk and enable us to predict future invasive species patterns across Colorado. We hope to apply these methods to improve our knowledge of how invasive species are altering fire return intervals and ecosystem health, guiding management and restoration.

sec.title: Idea #1: Carbon storage changes under climate change.
sec.p: Research Question: How does changing climatic conditions affect forest fire projections and carbon storage In the Colorado over the next 5 years?
Justification:

Wildfires are affected by climate change, and extreme fires are becoming more frequent due to increased drought, reduced humidity and soil moisture, and changing temperature Wu et al. (2023) . This poses a risk to carbon sequestration by forests, as more extreme fires release stored carbon from these forests; yet in some areas carbon storage is still predicted to increase Shmuel, Lazebnik, Glickman, Heifetz, & Price (2025) . In Colorado, forest fire is a relevant and important topic, therefor I want to scale data on climate and fire projections and then use that to predict carbon storage changes in Colorado over the next 5 years. This topic is ultimately important because changes in carbon sequestration greatly influence climate change, creating a feedback loop; as fires increase more carbon is on the atmosphere, increasing the effects of climate change, and therefor increasing fire potential Burton et al. (2024) . Fires are currently a threat to global climate change and emission goals because of the loss of carbon in forests, which increases the carbon in the atmosphere Burton et al. (2024).
Methods:

For the analysis of this question, I will use the drought and wildfire data that includes temperature, soil moisture, humidity, wind speed and fuel availability data (https://www.drought.gov/topics/fire). I will use multivariate statistics tests such as an ANOVA test to see how different climatic conditions and fire interact. I will use the climate and fire projections Shmuel et al. (2025) and land cover data for the west (from MRLC) to predict carbon storage change over the next 5 years. I will use the paper “Uncertainty in US forest carbon storage potential due to climate risks” to establish the relationship between fire and carbon storage loss Wu et al. (2023). This paper also has useful information for my calculations and conversions. I will also use data “Fire weakens land carbon sinks before 1.5 °C” Burton et al. (2024) to strengthen the connection between fire and carbon storage. I think that I will know more specifically how I will use them when I dig into the data, but for now I think they are both good resources to have. Ultimately, I will run correlation tests to see how the climatic variables interact with fire and my carbon storage projections.
Expected Outcome: I expect that due to increasingly aray climatic conditions, carbon storage will decrease in Colorado in the next 5 years

sec.title: Idea #2: Invasive plant- forest fire feedback loop.
sec.p: Research Question: How do non-native plants effect fire regimes and maintain dominance in Colorado? Justification: Invasive plants and forest fires are significant issues in Western US. Invasions by non-native plant species after fire can negatively impact important ecosystem services and lead to invasion-fire cycles, which ultimately further degrade ecosystems Prevéy et al. (2024) The impact of non-natives on forest fires is complex and can vary between vegetative functional type and geographic region Prevéy et al. (2024) . It has been established that native woody species rely on soil microbiomes to establish on burned soil, while non-native do not; this makes non-natives more likely to establish quickly after forest fires and then dominate these disturbed sites Escobedo et al. (2024). However, scientific understanding of how to restore plant-soil microbiome interactions after wildfires remains limited, leading to a key knowledge gap in post- fire ecosystem restoration Escobedo et al. (2024). This topic is ultimately important because it can inform management decisions on how to treat and restore areas pre and post fire in the arid west.

Methods: To answer this question, I will use the projections of post fire cover non-native and short-lived species under current and future climate conditions to create a baseline of what invasions will look like in the future Prevéy et al. (2024) . I will then use the information and data of different geographic regions and vegetative functional type to analyze how the different projected invasions will affect forest fire in the future Prevéy et al. (2024). I will use data from a study done in greenhouses that assesses nonnative and native plant survival post fire across different vegetative functional types in order to show how the different functional types of plants native to Colorado may be affected by fire Escobedo et al. (2024). For the functional types of native species in Colorado I will use FIA data from the USDA to show trends ( https://research.fs.usda.gov/products/dataandtools/tools/fia-datamart) . I will also use past wildfire data which is available from the article Prevéy et al. (2024) to show any correlation between functional plant group type and past forest fires.
Expected outcome: I expect that my research will show a increase in the invasives-fire feedback loop in Colorado, and that native plant distribution will decrease.

sec.title: Idea #3 : How Rising Temperatures Change Snowmelt Timing
sec.p: Justification: Snowmelt in alpine areas is a major water source for plants, animals and people. With climate change, warmer temperatures are causing snow to melt earlier Musselman, Clark, Liu, Ikeda, & Rasmussen (2017) . This can disrupt ecosystems and lead to water shortages downstream Climate Change (IPCC) (2021). Understanding these changes can help us plan for water use and protect alpine habitats.s.
Research Question: How does warming temperature affect when snow melts in alpine areas? Hypothesis: Warmer temperatures cause snow to melt earlier, shortening the snow season.

Proposed Methods: We’ll use snowpack data ( NOAA snowpack data) and temperature data ( from PRISM) for alpine regions in the Western U.S. Snowmelt timing will be tracked from 1980 to 2020, and we’ll look for trends linking higher temperatures to earlier snowmelt.
Expected Outcomes: We expect to see snow melting earlier as temperatures rise. This could lead to less water for ecosystems and people, showing the need for better water planning.

sec.title: Idea #4 : Fire Recovery in Coastal Shrublands
sec.p: Justification: Coastal shrublands are built to handle fire but frequent more intense fires from climate change could push them past their limit Keeley & Syphard (2016) . Studying how shrubs regenerate after fire especially under tough conditions like drought can help us manage and protect them better Enright, Fontaine, Lamont, Miller, & Westcott (2015).
Research Question: How do fire severity and rainfall affect shrubland regeneration? Hypothesis: Higher fire severity and less rainfall mean slower regeneration.

Proposed Methods: We’ll combine fire data with climate data to study post-fire regrowth in California shrublands. Vegetation recovery could be tracked from satellite images. We’ll use statistical models to figure out how fire and rainfall affect regeneration.
Expected Outcomes: Shrublands hit by severe fires and low rainfall will show slower recovery. These findings can guide better fire management and restoration planning.
